g4 Kg8 29. Qe2 Nb7 30. Rxc7 Rxc7 31. Rxc7 Qxc7 32. Qa6 Nc5 33. Qa8+ Kf7 34. h4
h6 35. Bc4 Be8 36. Be3 Ke7 37. g5 hxg5 38. hxg5 Kf7 39. Kg2 Ke7 40. Kg3 Kf7 41.
Kg4 Ke7 42. Kh4 Kf7 43. Kh3 Ke7 44. Kg2 Kf7 45. Bd2 Qb6 46. Be3 Qc7 {and
Carlsen claimed the threefold repetition, wrongly accepted by the chief
arbiter Geurt Gijssen. Morozevich signed the scoresheets and left the playing
area. Soon it was discovered that the arbiter shouldn't have accepted
Carlsen's claim, since in the first case (after 39.Kg2) it was Black's turn to
move. Carlsen agreed to continue the game. However, Morozevich wasn't there
anymore and later didn't want to resume the game... It is clear that the
normal course of the battle was broken, even if the result would have been a
draw anyway.} 1/2-1/2

before. However, history teaches us that opening theory tends to advance
slowly in positional lines, especially in games between co-nationals.

exchanges on a8 anf f8, followed by Kg2 and Rb1, the game will transpose to a
dead drawn rook + 2 pawns vs rook + 2 pawns ending. For once in this round,
the draw agreement looks entirely well timed. Nach dem Tausch auf a8 und f8,
gefolgt von Kg2 und Rb1, wird die Partie in ein totremises Endspiel Turm + 2
Bauern gegen Turm + 2 Bauern übergehen. Das einzige Mal in dieser Runde sieht
es so aus, als ob die Remisvereinbarung zum absolut richtigen Zeitpunkt kommt.}

O-O-O Nf6 9. f4 b5 10. e5 b4 11. exf6 bxc3 12. Qxc3 Bxf6 13. g4 Bb7 14. g5 Bxd4
15. Rxd4 O-O 16. Rd2 Rfc8 17. Rg1 Qd8 18. Bd4 Ne7 19. Qd3 Qa5 20. a3 Qa4 21.
Bh3 Nd5 22. Kb1 Nxf4 23. Qe3 Ng6 24. Rf1 Qb5 25. Qf2 Rf8 26. Bc5 Ne5 27. Bxf8
Rxf8 28. Rd4 Bd5 29. Rb4 Qc6 30. Qa7 Qc8 31. Rbf4 Nc4 32. R4f2 g6 33. Bg2 Bxg2
34. Rxg2 Qc6 35. Rgf2 Qb5 36. Qd4 Nxa3+ 37. Kc1 Nc4 38. h4 d5 39. b3 Nd6 40. h5
gxh5 41. Rh1 Nf5 42. Qf6 Qc5 43. Rxf5 exf5 44. Rxh5 Re8 45. Rh1 Qe3+ 46. Kb1
Qe6 47. Rh6 a5 48. Ka2 Qe4 49. Rh2 a4 50. Kb2 Re6 51. Qc3 axb3 52. cxb3 f4 53.
b4 d4 54. Qc8+ Re8 55. Qc4 Qe3 56. b5 f3 {A rather painful loss. White was in
control for the most time, but poor time management led to a couple of hasty
decisions, which cost me the game. As for Morozevich: he was ready for a sharp
battle and, although he can't be particularly proud of this game, his strategy
prevailed and brought him an important point. After this win he was on 3.5/4
and making five draws in the last games was enough to win the tournament. As
for myself: I could comfort myself with the fact that at least even my worst
tournament ever included several exciting games. Quite a poor reward for such
an awkward performance, to be sure. But there are new tournaments coming soon
- and hopefully next time I'll have an opportunity to comment for you on a
good victory, and not just another almost won game :)} 0-1
